abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            protecting and expanding opportunities for vulnerable groups
            in Guatemala. Central America's largest economy,
            Guatemala is a lower middle income country marked by social
            indicators that often fall below those of countries with far
            lower per capita incomes. The situation has been aggravated
            since 2008 with successive fuel, food, and economic crises
            as well as several natural disasters including a tropical
            storm which have put the progress made in the last decade in
            poverty and inequality reduction and health and education at
            risk. International Bank Research Development (IBRD) lending
            and technical programs have supported the country’s efforts
            to improve the lives of its people. The Bank significantly
            increased its development policy lending, to support the
            country in crisis response financing. The health project was
            executing civil works in twenty nine health clinics to an
            expected reduction in the ratio of indigenous to
            non-indigenous infant mortality in the project area by 10
            percent. The Rural Economic Development Project was
            providing technical assistance, credit and seed capital to
            twenty one indigenous producer associations to enhance their
            productivity and market access. Moreover, a rural roads
            project was rehabilitating close to 800 kilometers of roads,
            enhancing access to primary and secondary roads for a rural
            target population of 600,000. Assistance from the IBRD has
            focused on inclusive growth, reduction of poverty, and
            raising net primary school enrollment.
